elements.content: Five new coordination polymers, {[Co(OAc)2(bpe)(H2O)]·0.5(dmf)} n (1), {[Co(bpy)2(H2O)4][Co(tfa)(bpy)2(H2O)3](tfa)3·1.5(bpy)} n (2), [Co(tfa)2(dps)4] n (3), {[Co(tfa)2(bpe)4]·H2O} n (4), and [Co(tfa)2(bpp)4] n (5) (where AcO– = CH3CO2 –; tfa– = CF3CO2 –; bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane; dps = 4,4′-dipyridyl sulfide; dmf = N,N ′-dimethylformamide) were synthesized by the reactions of Co(OAc)2·4H2O and Co(tfa)2·4H2O with different dipyridyl ligands and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Compound 1 exhibits extended two-dimensional (2D) networks through the bridging AcO– and bpe ligands. The polymeric motifs in 2–5 are exclusively based on bipyridine-type ligands and results in 1D cationic chains in 2, similar charge-neutral double tapes in 3 and 4, and a 2D polymeric network in 5. In 2–5, the tfa anions coordinate to the Co(II) center in a monodentate mode. An impact of the anion’s fluorination on coordination modes and supramolecular architectures is registered. Magnetic measurements reveal almost vanishing exchange interactions in the layered materials 1 and 5. The correlation of mechanical properties and crystal structure has been demonstrated for 1.

Magnetic measurements reveal almost vanishing exchange interactions in the layered materials 1 and 5. The correlation of mechanical properties and crystal structure has been demonstrated for 1.

elements.content: Design of metal–organic materials (MOMs), a variety of the crystal engineering approach, offers a great potential for fabrication of future materials for numerous applications including guest inclusion, gas storage, luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, catalysis, and drug delivery. Co(II)-based coordination networks in particular are recognized as prototypes of future magnetic materials exhibiting ferromagnetic, antiferromagnetic properties, and examples of metamagnetism, function as effective heterogeneous and reusable catalysts for the regio-, stereo-, and chemoselective ring-opening reactions of epoxides and size-selective cyanation reactions of aldehydes and so forth. There are even perspectives for such materials to serve as adsorptive materials functionalized to deliver drug molecules incorporated either in the polymeric matrix of the biodegradable MOM or in its coordination scaffold. Solvatochromism as an inherent property of Co(II) coordination networks allows using them as sensors for small molecules showing guest selectivity and providing a response in the UV/vis/NIR spectral range to the guest inclusion.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design of metal-organic materials (MOMs), a variety of the crystal engineering approach, offers a great potential for fabrication of future materials for numerous applications including guest inclusion, gas storage, luminescence, nonlinear optics, magnetism, catalysis, and drug delivery. Co(II)-based coordination networks in particular are recognized as prototypes of future magnetic materials exhibiting ferromagnetic, antiferromagnetic properties, and examples of metamagnetism, function as effective heterogeneous and reusable catalysts for the regio-, stereo-, and chemoselective ring-opening reactions of epoxides and size-selective cyanation reactions of aldehydes and so forth. There are even perspectives for such materials to serve as adsorptive materials functionalized to deliver drug molecules incorporated either in the polymeric matrix of the biodegradable MOM or in its coordination scaffold. Solvatochromism as an inherent property of Co(II) coordination networks allows using them as sensors for small molecules showing guest selectivity and providing a response in the UV/vis/NIR spectral range to the guest inclusion.

elements.content: From the crystal engineering viewpoint the Co(II) coordination networks range from the homoligand Co(II) carboxylates to the mixed-ligand MOMs of different dimensionalities, the most populated library represent mixed-ligand solids where the carboxylic residues are combined with the neutral N-aromatic ligands or the ligands that bear both these functionalities in the same molecule. The Co(II)-based systems demonstrate examples of supramolecular isomerism as in [Co(NO3)2(bpe)1.5] n dictated by conformational freedom of the ligands, or crystal-to-crystal transformations.

The Co(II)-based systems demonstrate examples of supramolecular isomerism as in [Co(NO3)2(bpe)1.5] n   dictated by conformational freedom of the ligands, or crystal-to-crystal transformations.

elements.content: The utilization of ligands as molecular building blocks (MBB) that are similar in coordination ability but different in size and flexibility is considered to be an effective way to fabricate the arrays of periodic networks. Herein, the bis(pyridine) ligands in which N-donor pyridine rings are separated by different spacers have been chosen (Scheme ).

elements.content: The conformational rigidity/flexibility of the spacers provided access to periodic coordination networks with varying dimensionalities, 1D and 2D. The starting salts, Co(OAc)2·4H2O and Co(tfa)2·4H2O, allow evaluation of the impact of the anion’s fluorination on the mode of its coordination to the metal center and the final supramolecular architectures. Five new coordination polymers, {[Co(OAc)2(bpe)(H2O)]·0.5(dmf)} n (1), {[Co(bpy)2(H2O)4] [Co(tfa)(bpy)2(H2O)3](tfa)2·1.5(bpy)} n (2), {[Co(tfa)2(dps)4]} n (3), {[Co(tfa)2(bpe)4]·H2O} n (4), and {[Co(tfa)2(bpp)4]} n (5) were synthesized and their crystal structures were studied. The magnetic properties of 1 and 5 and the mechanical properties of 1 have been investigated.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

Materials and Methods

All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in Nujol on a FT IR Spectrum-100 PerkinElmer spectrometer within the range of 4000-400 cm-1.

elements.content: Magnetic dc susceptibility data of 1 and 5 were obtained using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer. The polycrystalline samples were compacted and immobilized into cylindrical PTFE capsules. The data were acquired as a function of the field (0.1–5.0 T at 2 K) and temperature (2.0–290 K at 0.1 T). All data were corrected for the contribution of the sample holder (PTFE capsule) and the diamagnetic contributions of compound 1 and 5 calculated from Pascal’s constants using tabulated values (−4.0 × 10–9 m3 mol–1 and −6.1 × 10–9 m3 mol–1, respectively).

elements.content: Diffraction measurements for 1–5 were carried out on an Xcalibur E diffractometer equipped with CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing Mo Kα radiation at room temperature. All calculations to solve the structures and to refine the models were carried out with SHELX97 program package. In all structures the C-bound H atoms were placed in calculated positions and were treated using a riding model approximation with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C), The O-bound H atoms in coordinated water molecules in 1 and 2 were found from differential Fourier maps, and their positions were restrained using the DFIX instruction. These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). The H atoms for the disordered water molecule in 4 were not localized. In 1, the dmf molecule is disordered around the inversion center. In 2, the CF3 groups of coordinated and one of noncoordinated tfa anions are disordered over two positions with occupancy factors of 0.79(1) and 0.21(1), and 0.78(1) and 0.22(1). One further outer-sphere tfa anion is disordered over two positions with the occupancy factors of 0.79(1) and 0.21(1). In 4, the CF3 group of tfa anion is disordered over two positions with occupancy factors of 0.56(1) and 0.44(1). Difficulties were encountered in the solution and refinement of structure 5 because of the pseudo-body-centered lattice and pseudo-merohedral twinning. The common procedure of space group determination based on unit cell parameters, intensity statistics, and systematic absences (programs XPREP and PLATON) suggested face centered orthorhombic lattice, mmm Laue class, and Ccca space group. The structure solution in this space group resulted in the model of structure with unreasonable disorder of more than half of total electronic density, although the structural motif was rational. One of two symmetry independent 2D polymeric layers was found to be disordered over two positions with about equal probabilities and metal···metal separation between two positions of about 1.3 Å. Moreover the geometry of the bridging bpp ligands in that disordered layer was violated. We were not able to obtain the structure refinement converged better than R 1 ∼ 0.13; a few data sets from different crystal samples were also tested. More careful analysis of data, including trial-and-error method, revealed that lattice should be primitive and monoclinic with the monoclinic angle close to 90°. The reintegration of data in monoclinic setting led to unit cell parameters a = 18.6416(10), b = 17.6594(7), c = 38.1138(19), β = 90.137(5)°, and allowed determination of primitive P21/c space group. The pseudo-face-centered lattice resulted in a group of reflections with h + l = 2n + 1 indices of weak intensities. Within the resolution of data the data set comprised only 499 reflections with I > 3σ(I) for this group with mean intensity of reflections only 1.4 and mean I/σ =0.8, while 4751 and 4886 reflections with I > 3σ(I) were found for groups of reflections with k + l = 2n + 1 and h + k = 2n + 1 indices, and corresponding mean intensity of reflections 21.2 and 21.3 and mean I/σ =2.7 and 2.8, respectively. Thereby, the pseudo-face-centered lattice resulted in poorly observed/unique reflections ratio in the data set. Refinement of the structure also revealed the expected pseudo-merohedral twinning (twin matrix 1 0 0 0 −1 0 0 0 −1) with the ratio of components 0.574:0.426. The refinement resulted in substantially ordered structure, and disorder was found only for positions of fluorine atoms in some tfa anions. The restrictions were applied to the thermal parameters of some C and F atoms. Figures were produced using MERCURY. Crystal data and details on the structure refinement are given in Table . The bond distances and angles in Co(II) coordination polyhedra are given in cif files.

These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). The H atoms for the disordered water molecule in 4 were not localized. In 2, the CF3 groups of coordinated and one of noncoordinated tfa anions are disordered over two positions with occupancy factors of 0.79(1) and 0.21(1), and 0.78(1) and 0.22(1). One further outer-sphere tfa anion is disordered over two positions with the occupancy factors of 0.79(1) and 0.21(1). Compounds 1–5 were prepared by the reaction of cobalt(II) acetate or cobalt(II) trifluoroacetate with different polydentate organic ligands in the CH3OH or CH3OH:dmf solutions. The IR spectra of complexes 1–5 exhibit very strong and broad bands due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching of coordinated carboxylic groups in the 1609–1564 (νasCOO) and 1458–1411 cm–1 (νsCOO) regions for acetate anions in complex 1, and in the 1703–1589 and 1465–1415 cm–1 regions for trifluoroacetate anions in 2–5, respectively. These bands overlap with the ν(CN) stretching vibrations of the pyridine rings. The IR spectra of 2–5 also display strong bands in the range 1203–1125 cm–1 arising from δ(C–F) asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of tfa– counteranions. The presence of the coordinated water molecules in complexes 1 and 2 is provided by broad signals at 3265 and 3229 cm–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and IR Characterization

Compounds 1-5 were prepared by the reaction of cobalt(II) acetate or cobalt(II) trifluoroacetate with different polydentate organic ligands in the CH3OH or CH3OH:dmf solutions. The IR spectra of complexes 1-5 exhibit very strong and broad bands due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching of coordinated carboxylic groups in the 1609-1564 (νasCOO) and 1458-1411 cm-1 (νsCOO) regions for acetate anions in complex 1, and in the 1703-1589 and 1465-1415 cm-1 regions for trifluoroacetate anions in 2-5, respectively. These bands overlap with the ν(CN) stretching vibrations of the pyridine rings. The IR spectra of 2-5 also display strong bands in the range 1203-1125 cm-1 arising from δ(C-F) asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of tfa- counteranions. The presence of the coordinated water molecules in complexes 1 and 2 is provided by broad signals at 3265 and 3229 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (Figure a). The Co(II) cation coordinates three AcO– anions, two bpe, and one water molecule. The N2O4-coordination surrounding the Co(II) atom represents the distorted octahedron that comprises four oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane [Co(1)-O: 2.071(2)–2.107(2) Å], and two nitrogen atoms in axial positions [Co(1)-N: 2.163(3) and 2.175(3) Å]. The bpe ligand is in anti-conformation, with a C–C–C–C torsion angle of 179.26°, the pyridine rings deviate from coplanarity as the interplanar angle of 9.38° indicates. This structural motif extends into a polymer via bridging AcO– anions and bpe ligands which link neighboring Co(II) cations along the c and a directions, respectively, and afford the 2D (4,4) coordination network (Figure b). The Co···Co separation across AcO– is 5.145 Å, and across bpe is 13.617 Å. The disordered dmf solvent molecules are accumulated in the interlayered space, held there by the π–π interactions with the bpe aromatic systems (Figure c). The reported Co(II) coordination polymer based on acetate, bpe, and dicyanamide (dca) ligands [Co3(OAc)4(bpe)3(dca)2] n adopts an infinite three-legged ladder-like structure where three parallel 1D {Co(bpe)} chains are connected by syn–syn and oxo-bridging acetato-ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c (Figure a). The Co(II) cation coordinates three AcO- anions, two bpe, and one water molecule. The N2O4-coordination surrounding the Co(II) atom represents the distorted octahedron that comprises four oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane [Co(1)-O: 2.071(2)-2.107(2) Å], and two nitrogen atoms in axial positions [Co(1)-N: 2.163(3) and 2.175(3) Å]. The bpe ligand is in anti-conformation, with a C-C-C-C torsion angle of 179.26°, the pyridine rings deviate from coplanarity as the interplanar angle of 9.38° indicates. This structural motif extends into a polymer via bridging AcO- anions and bpe ligands which link neighboring Co(II) cations along the c and a directions, respectively, and afford the 2D (4,4) coordination network (Figure b). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation across AcO- is 5.145 Å, and across bpe is 13.617 Å. The disordered dmf solvent molecules are accumulated in the interlayered space, held there by the π-π interactions with the bpe aromatic systems (Figure c). The reported Co(II) coordination polymer based on acetate, bpe, and dicyanamide (dca) ligands [Co3(OAc)4(bpe)3(dca)2] n  adopts an infinite three-legged ladder-like structure where three parallel 1D {Co(bpe)} chains are connected by syn-syn and oxo-bridging acetato-ligands.

elements.content: Structural details of 1. (a) Coordination environment of Co(II). (b) View of the 2D (4,4) network. (c) dmf inclusion in the crystal lattice, view approximately along c. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Molecules of dmf are shown in space-filling mode.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic centrosymmetric space group P1̅. The asymmetric part of the unit cell comprises two different complex cations, [Co(bpy)2(H2O)4]2+ and [Co(tfa)(bpy)2(H2O)3]+ (Figure a,b), three tfa– counteranions, and 1.5 bpy molecules. Similar to 1, the coordination cores of both Co(II) atoms represent the N2O4 distorted octahedra. The Co(1) is surrounded by four water molecules in the equatorial plane, and bpy ligands in axial positions [Co(1)-O: 2.077(4)–2.119(4) Å, Co(1)-N: 2.176(4) Å]. The coordination environment of Co(2) differs only by coordination of one tfa– anion in monodentate mode instead of one water molecule [Co(2)-O(H2): 2.057(4)–2.119(4) Å, Co(2)-O(tfa): 2.096(4) Å, and Co(2)-N: 2.160(4) and 2.174(4) Å]. The bpy molecules coordinated to the Co(1) and Co(2) metal centers adopt slightly different conformations with the dihedral angles between the pyridine rings of 26.46° and 10.14°, correspondingly. The structure extension occurs exclusively via bpy ligands that act as μ2-bridges and join the same Co atoms into two infinite linear cationic chains along the crystallographic a axis (Figure c). The Co···Co separation across the bpy is equal to the unit cell parameter a = 11.443 Å. The infinite 1D strands form along the b axis two types of stacks with the partially overlapping coordinated and noncoordinated bpy molecules (Figure e). In the crystal, networks of O–H···O and O–H···N hydrogen bonds hold the components (Figure f). The hydrogen bonding parameters for 2 are given in Table . The hydrophilic regions between two types of stacks are composed of the fluorine atoms and water molecules. In the same regions OH···N-type hydrogen bonds exist with participation of water molecules and noncoordinated bpy molecules. The previously reported anhydrous compound [Co(OAc)2(bpy)] n represents 1D coordination polymer that contains linear double Co–bpy–Co chains bridged by AcO– groups.

The Co(1) is surrounded by four water molecules in the equatorial plane, and bpy ligands in axial positions [Co(1)-O: 2.077(4)-2.119(4) Å, Co(1)-N: 2.176(4) Å]. The coordination environment of Co(2) differs only by coordination of one tfa- anion in monodentate mode instead of one water molecule [Co(2)-O(H2): 2.057(4)-2.119(4) Å, Co(2)-O(tfa): 2.096(4) Å, and Co(2)-N: 2.160(4) and 2.174(4) Å]. The bpy molecules coordinated to the Co(1) and Co(2) metal centers adopt slightly different conformations with the dihedral angles between the pyridine rings of 26.46° and 10.14°, correspondingly. The structure extension occurs exclusively via bpy ligands that act as μ2-bridges and join the same Co atoms into two infinite linear cationic chains along the crystallographic a axis (Figure c). The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation across the bpy is equal to the unit cell parameter a = 11.443 Å. The infinite 1D strands form along the b axis two types of stacks with the partially overlapping coordinated and noncoordinated bpy molecules (Figure e). In the crystal, networks of O-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds hold the components (Figure f). The hydrogen bonding parameters for 2 are given in Table . elements.content: Compounds 3 and 4 crystallize in the chiral hexagonal space groups P6222 and P62. The structures’ organization is provided by the same mode of tfa– anion coordination to the metal centers and the angular conformations of the bridging dps and bpe neutral ligands. Metal cations in 3 and 4 reside on a sixfold 62 screw axis; thus, their coordination polyhedra have local C 2 symmetry (Figure a,b). Whereas each Co(II) ion in 1 and 2 adopts an N2O4 coordination environment, N4O2 environments result in 3 and 4, derived from four N-bases that occupy the coordination sites in the square vertices [Co(1)-N: 2.169(3) Å in 3, 2.147(5)/2.158(5) Å in 4]. The two other sites are occupied by the monodentate-coordinated tfa– anions [Co(1)-O: 2.105(6) Å in 3, 2.109(3) Å in 4]. The dps and bpe ligands are linked to the Co(II) atoms in a double-stranded bridge fashion, thus extending the structure to 1D double tapes composed of the 20-membered and 22-membered metallo-rings with Co···Co separations of 10.049 and 10.028 Å across the cavities in 3 and 4 (Figure c,d). The tapes’ organization reproduces features found in the coordination polymers {[Co(dps)2(dmf)2](ClO4)2·2(dps)} n , {[Co(dps)2(H2O)2](abs)2·2(H2O)} n , where Habs = 4-aminobenzenesulfonic acid, {[Co(dps)2(NCS)2]·2H2O} n , {[Co(dps)2(N3)2]·0.5(H2O)} n , and {[Co(bpe)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2(H2O)} n . Unlike the reported examples, the helical packing of the tapes in 3 and 4 provided small voids (59 and 61 Å3 as calculated by PLATON) occupied by the disordered water molecules in 4 (Figure e,f).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. An asymmetric unit comprises components of two similar periodic 2D networks (A and B). The coordination environments for all four symmetry independent Co(II) cations are similar, and one of the nodes is shown in Figure a. Similar to 3 and 4, each Co(II) atom has an N4O2 coordination environment, composed of four crystallographically unique bpp molecules, forming a distorted square plane with the Co–N distances falling in the range 2.132(8)–2.203(7) Å. The oxygen atoms of two tfa– anions complete the octahedral geometry by occupying the axial positions [Co–O distances being in the range 2.065(6)–2.121(7) Å] and acting in a monodentate mode similar to 2, 3, and 4. The bpp molecule can adopt various conformations when it acts as a ligand. It was registered in 5 where eight crystallographically unique bpp ligands adjust two essentially different conformations. In terms suggested by Carlucci et al. the ligands adjust TT and GG′ conformations since the N···N distances across the bpp ligands are in the ranges 9.79(1)–9.82(1) Å and 8.32(1)–8.40(1) Å, respectively (the torsion angles along the aliphatic chains in eight ligands are given in cif file). Each bpp ligand bridges two Co(II) ions, and each Co(II) ion links four bpp ligands, forming a periodic 2D grid structure with (4,4) topology (Figure b). The sizes of the meshes in two similar grids were determined by Co···Co separations equal to 12.03 × 13.70 Å. The two crystallographically unique 2D networks are coupled due to mutual interweaving forming the double-layer motif (Figure c). The −CH2–CH2–CH2– chain from the bpp spacers in the double-layer motif can be involved in the lipophilic interactions, but in contrast to the cited work, such interactions take place between bpp ligands of different conformations. The thickness of the layer is roughly estimated as 1/4c = 9.53 Å (Figure d).

elements.content: In comparison to different transition metal ions, the magnetochemical analysis of Co(II) complexes proves to be difficult since its orbital momentum is not completely quenched by the ligand field. In terms of ligand field theory, the 4 F ground term of the Co(II) ion in a weak octahedral ligand field splits into 4T1g(F), 4T2g, and 4A2g, while 4 P does not split transforming into 4T1g(P) state. Due to the 4T1g(F) ground state, the magnetic properties of such complexes are characterized by significant temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment μeff caused by the orbital momentum contributions. In addition, the first excited term 4 P of the free ion transforms into a 4T1g(P) state, i.e., a state with the same symmetry as the ground state, leading to a ground state that is mixed depending on the field-strength of the ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetochemical Analysis

In comparison to different transition metal ions, the magnetochemical analysis of Co(II) complexes proves to be difficult since its orbital momentum is not completely quenched by the ligand field. In terms of ligand field theory, the 4 F ground term of the Co(II) ion in a weak octahedral ligand field splits into 4T1g(F), 4T2g, and 4A2g, while 4 P does not split transforming into 4T1g(P) state. Due to the 4T1g(F) ground state, the magnetic properties of such complexes are characterized by significant temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment μeff caused by the orbital momentum contributions. In addition, the first excited term 4 P of the free ion transforms into a 4T1g(P) state, i.e., a state with the same symmetry as the ground state, leading to a ground state that is mixed depending on the field-strength of the ligands.

elements.content: Due to two types of ligands (N and O) and the coordination geometry of the Co(II) centers in 1 and 5, the ligand field adopts distorted D 4h rather than octahedral symmetry leading to further splitting of the states. Furthermore, due to the long bridging ligands between the Co(II) centers in a network, the exchange interactions are expected to be very weak. Thus, these interactions are treated by the mean field approximation although they are expected to be asymmetric. To model the magnetic data, the computational framework CONDON 2.0 has been used. In the fitting procedures, interelectronic repulsion, spin–orbit coupling, electrostatic effects of the ligand field, as well as the Zeeman effect of an external magnetic field have been considered using the full basis set of 120 microstates of a high-spin Co(II) center (3d7) in addition to the mean field approximation.
elements.clean_text: Due to two types of ligands (N and O) and the coordination geometry of the Co(II) centers in 1 and 5, the ligand field adopts distorted D 4h  rather than octahedral symmetry leading to further splitting of the states. Furthermore, due to the long bridging ligands between the Co(II) centers in a network, the exchange interactions are expected to be very weak. Thus, these interactions are treated by the mean field approximation although they are expected to be asymmetric. To model the magnetic data, the computational framework CONDON 2.0 has been used. In the fitting procedures, interelectronic repulsion, spin-orbit coupling, electrostatic effects of the ligand field, as well as the Zeeman effect of an external magnetic field have been considered using the full basis set of 120 microstates of a high-spin Co(II) center (3d7) in addition to the mean field approximation.

elements.content: The effective magnetic moment μeff at 0.1 T as a function of the temperature and the molar magnetization M m at 2 K as a function of the applied magnetic field are shown in Figure for compounds 1 and 5. Both compounds exhibit a similar behavior: the effective magnetic moment approaches a value of 5.00 μB (1) and 5.07 μB (5) at 290 K, which is well in the range of 4.30–5.20 μB that is expected for a noninteracting high-spin Co(II) center. With reduction in temperature, the moment steadily decreases to 3.82 μB (1) and 4.02 μB (5) at 2 K typical for single Co(II) centers. The molar magnetization of both complexes reaches approximately 2.3 N A μB at an external field of 5 T and shows saturation.

elements.content: The ligand field parameters B 0 2, B 0 4, and B 4 4 (Wybourne notation) and the molecular-field parameter λMF were varied to fit the molar magnetic susceptibility data. The one-electron spin–orbit coupling parameter ζ = 533 cm–1 and the Racah parameters B = 1115 cm–1 and C = 4366 cm–1 were treated as constants during the fitting procedures that use the Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm. The best fit results are given in Table and are shown as solid lines in Figure .

Note that although the positive sign of the molecular-field parameter indicates a ferromagnetic exchange interaction, the exchange interaction is very weak (J ex ≈ 0.01 cm–1 for both compounds in the “–2J ex” convention). Within the fitting error, the calculated molecular-field parameter is therefore in agreement with noninteracting or even very weak antiferromagnetically coupled Co(II) centers. Due to the distorted octahedral symmetry of the ligands and the spin–orbit coupling, the 4T1g ground term splits into six Kramer’s doublets that span an energy range of 1389 cm–1 with a gap of 197 cm–1 between the lowest two doublets for complex 1. For compound 5, the six doublets are distributed over a range of 1591 cm–1, and the two lowest ones show a difference of 168 cm–1.

For compound 5, the six doublets are distributed over a range of 1591 cm-1, and the two lowest ones show a difference of 168 cm-1.

elements.content: The mechanical properties of MOMs deserve growing attention since they are essential variables for a majority of possible applications. The insufficient progress in this area is on one hand due to the difficulty in preparing suitable single crystals needed for mechanical studies, and on the other due to the restrictions of existing mechanical testing techniques. The recent publication from Cheetham’s group summarizes a few known examples of this type of research that demonstrate essential advantages of nanoindentation for estimation of the stability limits of MOMs, anisotropy of hardness in different directions, and contribution of different types of interatomic and intermolecular interaction to the overall crystal stability.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanical Properties

The mechanical properties of MOMs deserve growing attention since they are essential variables for a majority of possible applications. The insufficient progress in this area is on one hand due to the difficulty in preparing suitable single crystals needed for mechanical studies, and on the other due to the restrictions of existing mechanical testing techniques. The recent publication from Cheetham's group summarizes a few known examples of this type of research that demonstrate essential advantages of nanoindentation for estimation of the stability limits of MOMs, anisotropy of hardness in different directions, and contribution of different types of interatomic and intermolecular interaction to the overall crystal stability.

elements.content: The very limited reported data on mechanical properties of MOMs encouraged us to study the microstructure and anisotropy of mechanical properties of layered material 1. Light microscopy was used to estimate the shape, dimensions, and surface morphology of as-grown crystals, and the indentation images. Strength characteristics (Young modulus, E, and dynamical nanohardness, H) were studied by using the nanoindentation (NI) tester equipped with a trihedral diamond Berkovich pyramid as an indenter. The determination of the hardness and Young modulus was made by evaluation of the NI P-h curves using the Oliver-Pharr method. Three peak loads, P, were employed for dynamical indentation: 5, 10, and 20 mN. The following mode was used: indentation loading for 20 s, exposure to the load for 5 s, and unloading for 20 s. Compound 1 crystallizes as approximately regular prisms and more distorted sphenoidal crystals. The crystals’ overall length reached 2–2.5 mm; their width varied from 0.1 to 0.5 mm. For investigation of the different loadings the crystal shown in Figure has been chosen. The stratified structure was clearly visible on the crystal surface. The regions of red color with different tints alternate along the crystal. These regions demonstrate well-defined strata (Figure ).

The determination of the hardness and Young modulus was made by evaluation of the NI P-h curves using the Oliver-Pharr method. Three peak loads, P, were employed for dynamical indentation: 5, 10, and 20 mN. The following mode was used: indentation loading for 20 s, exposure to the load for 5 s, and unloading for 20 s. Compound 1 crystallizes as approximately regular prisms and more distorted sphenoidal crystals. The crystals' overall length reached 2-2.5 mm; their width varied from 0.1 to 0.5 mm. For investigation of the different loadings the crystal shown in Figure  has been chosen. The stratified structure was clearly visible on the crystal surface. The regions of red color with different tints alternate along the crystal. These regions demonstrate well-defined strata (Figure ).

elements.content: Representative P–h curves obtained under indentation of the as-grown facet of the crystal 1 by the three peak loads are shown in Figure . One can see a different shape of the curves at the loading part. On the whole, all of them are smooth, indicating that the deformation process during indenter penetration occurs relatively homogeneously. However, the load increase leads to the change of the deformation mechanism. Under light loads (5 and 10 mN) the curve run has a small vibrating form. This signifies an alternating contribution of the elastic and plastic deformation to mass transfer during the indentation creation. The fraction of plastic deformation essentially grows with load increase (20 mN) resulting in the appearance of some pop-ins. This result correlates with findings observed in the hydrogen-bonded 2D coordination polymer {Cu1.5(H2O)[O3PCH2CO2]} n (polymorphs I and II), where the P–h curves demonstrate the periodic pop-ins, as well. Whereas the pop-ins registered on the I and II polymorphs appear at an indentation depth h max ∼ 500 nm, in our case pop-in steps show up only when the indentation depth reached the value h max > 1.5 μm. This fact denotes the higher elastic–plastic properties of crystal 1 as compared with the reported material. Small creep effects are observed on all P–h curves (Figure a, b, and c) during the hold time of 5 s at peak load as evidence of prolonged plastic deformation under constant load. The average values of elastic (Young’s) modulus, E, and hardness, H, obtained from the P–h curves are presented in Table . The average error bars correspond to the standard deviation for given values of load.

Whereas the pop-ins registered on the I and II polymorphs appear at an indentation depth h max ~ 500 nm, in our case pop-in steps show up only when the indentation depth reached the value h max > 1.5 μm. This fact denotes the higher elastic-plastic properties of crystal 1 as compared with the reported material. Small creep effects are observed on all P-h curves (Figure a, b, and c) during the hold time of 5 s at peak load as evidence of prolonged plastic deformation under constant load. The average values of elastic (Young's) modulus, E, and hardness, H, obtained from the P-h curves are presented in Table . The average error bars correspond to the standard deviation for given values of load.

elements.content: Both mechanical parameters, the elastic modulus and hardness, showed the dependence on the load value. The load increase caused diminution of E and H. The maximal values of these parameters were obtained by using the minimal load, P = 5 mN: 12.54 and 0.6 GPa for E and H, respectively. The data summarized in Table are in line with the reported so-called “porous intermediates” and the closest to those found for MOM [Cu2F(HF)(HF2)(pyz)4][SbF6)2] n (pyz = pyrazine), where the mechanical parameters for the {001} plane were E ≈ 12–14 GPa and H ≈ 0.6–0.7 GPa.

elements.content: The curve shape is smooth with light vibration for all planes on the loading part and on the unloading part. Some inhomogeneity is observed at the initial stage of the loading part (up to P ∼ 1.5 mN and h < 400 nm) for all studied planes. It may be attributed to the indentation size effect (ISE) in the near-surface layers of material. The smooth indenter penetration takes place at P > 1.5 mN, which indicates a homogeneous movement of material under action of the increasing load. The most significant material movement occurred under deformation of the (010) plane, which led to the mechanical parameter diminution (Table ).

As follows from Table , an essential anisotropy is observed if the mechanical parameter values are compared for all investigated planes. The (001) plane is the hardest one, with the maximal values of E and H: 13.07 and 0.73 GPa, respectively. The (010) plane is the least hard one: E = 4.92 GPa, H = 0.24 GPa. Thereby, the maximal anisotropy coefficient for Young’s modulus amounts to k E = E (001)/E (010) = 2.66, and for hardness: k H = H (001)/H (010) = 3.04. The mechanical parameters for the (100) plane are close to those for (001): E = 12.54 GPa, H = 0.61 GPa, i.e., k E = E (001)/E (100) = 1.04, and k H = H (001)/H (100) = 1.2. Our results present convincing evidence that the crystal orientation dominated by the metal–organic layers with the van der Waals and π–π stacking interactions between the layers is the least robust from the mechanical properties standpoint.

elements.content: In summary, five coordination polymers {[Co(OAc)2(bpe)(H2O)]·0.5(dmf)} n (1), {[Co(bpy)2(H2O)4][Co(tfa)(bpy)2(H2O)3](tfa)3·1.5(bpy)} n (2), [Co(tfa)2(dps)4] n (3), {[Co(tfa)2(bpe)4]·H2O} n (4), and [Co(tfa)2(bpp)4] n (5) were prepared and their crystal structures were explored. The structural function of trifluoroacetate vs acetate in the formation of Co(II) coordination polymer networks, together with the effect of the different length and conformational flexibility of bipyridyl-based ligands, was investigated. Contrary to 1 with its bidentate-bridging mode of the AcO– anion, the tfa-containing solids 2–5 reveal the monodentately coordinated tfa ligands. Compound 2 contains monocoordinated and noncoordinated disordered tfa– counteranions, possibly due to the rigid bpy molecules that impede access to the metal center for the second sterically bulky tfa– anion. The extension of polymeric motifs in 2–5 occurs exclusively via bipyridine-type ligands and results in 1D cationic chains in 2, charge-neutral similar double tapes in 3 and 4, and a 2D polymeric network in 5. On one hand, the higher the flexibility of these neutral ligands, the higher the dimensionality of the final materials is. On the other hand, the incorporation of tfa– anions restricts the dimensionality and enhances the hydrophilicity of the solids as is evident from structure 2 comprising coordinated water molecules, and structure 4 that reveals some adsorbed noncoordinated water molecules. Magnetic measurements for the two layered structures 1 and 5 indicate that the Co(II) centers interact only weakly. The mechanical properties for 1 reveal pronounced anisotropy of hardness with the most soft layer facet.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, five coordination polymers {[Co(OAc)2(bpe)(H2O)]⋅0.5(dmf)} n  (1), {[Co(bpy)2(H2O)4][Co(tfa)(bpy)2(H2O)3](tfa)3⋅1.5(bpy)} n  (2), [Co(tfa)2(dps)4] n  (3), {[Co(tfa)2(bpe)4]⋅H2O} n  (4), and [Co(tfa)2(bpp)4] n  (5) were prepared and their crystal structures were explored. The structural function of trifluoroacetate vs acetate in the formation of Co(II) coordination polymer networks, together with the effect of the different length and conformational flexibility of bipyridyl-based ligands, was investigated. Contrary to 1 with its bidentate-bridging mode of the AcO- anion, the tfa-containing solids 2-5 reveal the monodentately coordinated tfa ligands. Compound 2 contains monocoordinated and noncoordinated disordered tfa- counteranions, possibly due to the rigid bpy molecules that impede access to the metal center for the second sterically bulky tfa- anion. The extension of polymeric motifs in 2-5 occurs exclusively via bipyridine-type ligands and results in 1D cationic chains in 2, charge-neutral similar double tapes in 3 and 4, and a 2D polymeric network in 5. On one hand, the higher the flexibility of these neutral ligands, the higher the dimensionality of the final materials is. On the other hand, the incorporation of tfa- anions restricts the dimensionality and enhances the hydrophilicity of the solids as is evident from structure 2 comprising coordinated water molecules, and structure 4 that reveals some adsorbed noncoordinated water molecules. Magnetic measurements for the two layered structures 1 and 5 indicate that the Co(II) centers interact only weakly. The mechanical properties for 1 reveal pronounced anisotropy of hardness with the most soft layer facet.
